description.en: The course is comprised of interactive lectures and seminars designed to provide a multidisciplinary introduction to Ukraine and its recent socio-political changes, with a special focus on Ukraine's resilience in countering Russia's invasion and prospects for the future.
description.et: Kursus koosneb interaktiivsetest loengutest ja seminaridest, mille eesmärk on anda multidistsiplinaarne sissejuhatus Ukraina uuringutesse ja Ukraina hiljutistesse sotsiaalpoliitilistesse muutustesse, keskendudes eelkõige Ukraina vastupanuvõimele Venemaa sissetungi vastu võitlemisel ja tulevikuväljavaadetele.

objectives.en:
The course aims to introduce Ukraine from different perspectives (historical, political,
sociological, cultural, media and digital studies), examine Ukraine's resilience in countering Russia's invasion, and reflect on Ukraine's role in contemporary Europe and the world.
objectives.et: Kursuse eesmärgiks on tutvustada Ukraina riiki ja ühiskonda läbi erinevate vaatenurkade (ajalooline, poliitiline, sotsioloogiline, kultuuri-, meedia- ja digiuuringud) ja uurida Ukraina vastupanuvõimet Venemaa sissetungi vastu võitlemisel ning arutleda Ukraina rolli üle tänapäeva Euroopas ja maailmas.

learning_outcomes.en: Upon successful completion of the course, student should be able to:
learning_outcomes.et: Kursuse edukal läbimisel peaks üliõpilane suutma järgmist:

learning_outcomes.en: * understand and explain the socio-political situation in contemporary Ukraine as well as its historical and institutional preconditions;
learning_outcomes.et: * mõista ja selgitada tänapäeva Ukraina sotsiaalpoliitilist olukorda ning selle ajaloolisi ja institutsionaalseid eeldusi;

learning_outcomes.en: * analyze recent developments in Ukraine through historical, political, sociological, and other perspectives;
learning_outcomes.et: * analüüsida hiljutisi arenguid Ukrainas ajalooliste, poliitiliste, sotsioloogiliste ja muude vaatenurkade kaudu;

learning_outcomes.en: * critically assess various discourses of Ukraine, its history, culture, society, politics etc. and understand the reasons behind them;
learning_outcomes.et: * hinnata kriitiliselt erinevaid diskursusi Ukrainast, selle ajaloost, kultuurist, ühiskonnast, poliitikast jne ning mõista nende tagamaid;

learning_outcomes.en: * compare the Ukrainian case with developments in other countries;
learning_outcomes.et: * võrrelda Ukraina juhtumit teiste riikide arengutega;

learning_outcomes.en: * locate Ukraine within European and global international structures;
learning_outcomes.et: * kirjeldada Ukraina asukohta Euroopa ja ülemaailmsetes rahvusvahelistes struktuurides;

learning_outcomes.en: * conduct an independent academic, applied or policy study on Ukraine.
learning_outcomes.et: * viia läbi sõltumatut akadeemilist, rakenduslikku või poliitilist uuringut Ukraina kohta.

notes.et:
About prerequisite knowledge:
The course will provide necessary background material to all course participants. Beyond that, participants should possess basic skills of intelligent online communication and familiarity with digital tools for online information searching and learning. Participants should be able to work independently as well as to work in teams and engage in polite and tolerant discussions.

Students of this course are expected to be aware of and follow UT rules regarding plagiarism (see, 
https://sotsiaalteadused.ut.ee/en/academic-fraud and Study Regulations on the same webpage).

Compentences required: communication, IT skills, information management, time management and planning skills, problem-solving, critical thinking, teamwork, intercultural communication skills.

description.et:
Active participation in class and submission of own questions and reflections for group discussions. To earn points, each student is expected to (a) submit questions and reflections to the lecturer by the end of the day of respective seminars and (b) contribute with relevant reasoned comments during seminars. More informative, insightful, original, and persuasive contributions result in higher grades.

Maximum grade per seminar is 5 points. For 8 seminars, the total maximum grade is 40 points.

Up to 5 points (A) - participation is very active and respectful of others, with a group leadership role, reading is wide, the arguments are analytical, supported by relevant examples, speeches are creative and persuasive.
Up to 4 points (B) - participation is active, reading is wide, arguments are analytical and supported by relevant examples, speeches are interesting and engaging, very good expression.
Up to 3 points (C) - participation is active; reading is not limited only to main arguments, analytical skills are sufficient, speeches are interesting, expression is clear.
Up to 2 points (D) - participation is noticeable, demonstration of compulsory literature and main arguments is sufficient, analytical skills are sufficient, expression is clear.
Up to 1 point (E) - participation is insufficient, knowledge of compulsory literature is sufficient, arguments are weak or incomplete, the skill of expression is sufficient.

The lecturer or TA will evaluate seminar discussions.

Each paper should explore a particular issue raised in the course, argue a specific point, and be targeted towards a certain audience in society in the spirit of citizen science. Paper length is between 1000-1500 words, excluding references and a bibliography. Students should choose their topics according to personal interest and discuss them with the lecturer. Selected essays will be encouraged to be published online as blog posts.

Topic choice deadlines: 1st essay – by the end of Friday of the 3rd week, 2nd essay – by the end Friday of of the 7th week. Only the topics sent before the deadlines will receive feedback.

Submission deadlines: 1st essay – by the end of Friday of the 5th week, 2nd essay – by the end Friday of of the 9th week. Each calendar day of submission delay deducts 5 points from the respective essay grade.

Maximum grade for an essay is 20 points. For 2 essays, the total maximum grade is 40 points.

Assessment criteria (each is worth 4 points max):
- Presentation style (text formatting, language clarity, accuracy and consistency of references).
- Material quality (relevance, credibility, and extent of sources).
- Analysis quality (overall logic and structure, level of analysis and synthesis).
- Creativity (critical thinking, new ideas and interpretations, a distinct individual style).
- Impact (how interesting, challenging, and persuasive a text is for a reader).

Up to 20 points (A) – the form is excellent; the choice, amount and relevance of references is notable; the depth of the analysis, the level of independent interpretation, and logic is remarkable; the interpretation of the subject is innovative and persuasive; the text is outstanding.
Up to 16 points (B) – the form is excellent; the choice, amount and relevance of references is very good; thorough and logical analysis of connections and references; interpretations are creative and persuasive.
Up to 12 points (C) – the form complies with the requirements and is correct; references are relevant and sufficient; analysis and logic are proper, but with some weaknesses; interpretations are of moderate novelty and persuasiveness.
Up to 8 points (D) – the form complies with the requirements and is correct; references are minimal, but relevant; the analysis is mostly understandable, logical and associated; interpretations are of some interest.
Up to 4 points (E) – the form overall complies with the requirements and is correct; references are minimal and questionable; the elements of analysis and logic are in place; the narrative is overall independent, but with significant gaps.

The lecturer or TA will evaluate essays.

A collective presentation of a group inquiry of a particular aspect of Ukrainian society to be presented at the final seminar.

Topic choice deadline: group presentation – by the end of Friday of the 11th week. Only the topics sent before the deadline will receive feedback.

Draft presentation should be sent to the lecturer by the end of Friday of the 13th week. Only the draft presentation slides sent before the deadline will receive feedback.

Final presentation should be sent to the lecturer by the end of Friday of the 15th week.

Maximum grade for a group presentation is 20 points.

grade_preconditions.et: To be considered for the final assessment (group presentation), students are expected to earn at least 31 point for both assignments (seminar discussions and 2 argumentative essays) in total.

grade_evaluation.et:
The course consists of 100 points. To pass the course students need to get at least 51 points accumulated from all assessed assignments:
The final assessment of the course consists of the following:
- Contributions to seminar discussions: 5x8=40 points max.
- Argumentative essays: 2x20=40 points max.
- Group presentation: 20 points max.
- Total: 100 points max.
Provided that the prerequisites are met, a passing grade is determined by a final computation of points higher or equal to 51 out of 100.

debt_elimination.et: By an individual agreement with the course instructor
